Hi there! Itâ€™s a pleasure to meet you virtually :relaxed: 

I thought I would start us off by telling you a little bit about myself. My full name is Venezia, but feel free to call me Venny. Iâ€™m a Junior Games Designer at Mojiworks and we make social games for mobile. Weâ€™ve recently launched our firstmeans on Snapchat ðŸ¥³ Itâ€™s a cool cooking game called Ready Chef Go.

Other than that, I went to the University of Southampton and graduated with First Class Honours in Games Design and Art. 

In addition to being a designer at Mojiworks, I also work on a few side projects where I make 3D environments. 

Anyway, I hope this helps you and Iâ€™d love to hear a bit more about you too. Iâ€™m particularly interested in what I can help you with the most and what you are hoping to gain out of the mentoring programme :relaxed:
Hi, nice to meet you to, my names is Alexander, or Alex whatever you prefer, i am a 3rd year games design student at BCE, (big creative education)
That sounds great, how have you been finding your studies and your course so far?

it's been quite interesting, i havent been learning as much as i thought i would be learning, but the people that i have met along the way have encouraged me to learn a bit more outside of college times, stuff such as making my own games and the like.
It has been proving quite hard to do by myself however

I can absolutely understand that, I had quite a few people on my university degree who felt very similarly. However, itâ€™s amazing that youâ€™re doing extra learning and making games outside of college, you should definitely keep that up. I have found that oftentimes, itâ€™s exactly those side projects that make the best portfolios. What would you say some of the things you are finding most challenging?

Also, as a side note, I will always try to respond as soon as possible, but keep in mind sometimes it might take a day or so if itâ€™s busy :sweat_smile: Hope thatâ€™s okay!
oh, dont worry about it, i'm quite busy sometimes aswell, as for the what i find most challenging, well in terms of making games coding would probably rank number 1
but honestly i think that applies to alot of people

Thats my top most challenging bit as well :sweat_smile: But the good news is that as a designer or artist, you only need to have a basic literacy of programming. The more you understand the better, but you day to day all you really need is to have some familiarity with it. Usually you will have a passionate programmer on the team who can really get into the nitty gritty.

Now, I think it would be helpful if you thought about some questions for me, just so I can help you in the best way possible :blush:

1. Is there anything specific you would like some advice on at the minute? This might be college related, very happy to review course work things if you think it would be helpful, just let me know what you need :relaxed:
2. What are you interested in doing after college? Would you like to pursue a university degree or aim straight for industry or something entirely different? I can help out with recent advice for both.
3. Just as a general thing, feel free to send over any materials like CVs or portfolios/websites. Iâ€™d love to see your work and I am more than happy to give some tips on how to make it job/uni application ready.
But yeah, just anything at all youâ€™d like to ask/know, feel free to ask :blush:
oh, advice well, can i ask which modelling software you use?, as for after college i think i would be heading to university, but i would also like to be in an apprenticeship while im in uni
as for my work well, i have an art-station but its quite bare at the moment as i am considering which pieces of art to scrap and which to keep for my portfolio <https://www.artstation.com/fractals>
